discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
Reregister the Microsoft.DesktopVirtualization resource provider for the Azure subscription Â©: This ensures that the necessary resource provider is registered to support Azure Virtual Desktop features.
Create a private endpoint by using the feed target sub-resource (E): This allows you to create a private endpoint specifically for the Azure Virtual Desktop feed, ensuring secure and private connectivity.

AC
For Azure Virtual Desktop, the global target sub-resource is typically used to allow secure access to Azure Virtual Desktop's global service, which handles session brokering and management functions.
The Microsoft.DesktopVirtualization resource provider manages resources related to Azure Virtual Desktop. Reregistering it ensures that your subscription has the latest functionalities and capabilities needed to support private endpoint connections.

questions.question_text:
You have an Azure Virtual Desktop deployment that contains a host pool named Pool1. Pool1 contains three session hosts.

You need to implement a private endpoint connection for Pool.

Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents part of the solution.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

choices.D: Create a private endpoint by using the connection target sub-resource.
choices.E: Create a private endpoint by using the feed target sub-resource.
choices.A: Create a private endpoint by using the global target sub-resource.
choices.C: Reregister the Microsoft.DesktopVirtualization resource provider for the Azure subscription.
choices.B: Reregister the Microsoft.VirtualMachineImages resource provider for the Azure subscription.

discussion.content:
Host 1 should be Windows Server 2019 Datacenter - x64 Gen2, because
1. Trusted launch only works with Gen2
2. RDS session host role is not included in Server Core. So it doesn't support 15 concurrent users.
https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/server-core/server-core-removed-roles

comments.content: It is recommendation that you should not have mixed OS in same host pool. Not limit, just a bad design still. So I agree that not the best question but possible

discussion.content:
This is a bad Question! 

Fist off, you cannot have mixed OS versions in the same host Pool. So the premise that you plan to deploy the two prescribed hosts to HostPool1 is flawed from the start. 

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-desktop/prerequisites?tabs=portal

If you have existing session hosts in the host pool, make a note of the virtual machine size, the image, and name prefix that was used. All session hosts in a host pool should be the same configuration, including the same identity provider. For example, a host pool shouldn't contain some session hosts joined to Azure AD and some session hosts joined to an Active Directory domain.

Next the answer given is wrong for Host1. As Leocan mentioned Server core does not support RDP or any visual interface only command line. So it wouldn't be used for AVD

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-desktop/prerequisites?tabs=portal#operating-systems-and-licenses
These guys crack me up. Server core does not have a GUI. I don't think it even contains explorer.exe.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
Will need to be enable/configure at the Subscription level

Selected Answer: E
To enable Azure Virtual Desktop per-user access pricing, you need to configure it at the subscription level. This setting applies to all users within the subscription.

So, the correct answer is:

E. Sub1

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. New-AzResourceGroupDeployment

To provision an Azure Virtual Desktop deployment using an ARM template with PowerShell, you should use the New-AzResourceGroupDeployment cmdlet. This cmdlet allows you to deploy resources defined in an ARM template to a resource group.

questions.question_text:

You create an Azure Resource Manager (ARM) template named AVD.json that defines an Azure Virtual Desktop deployment.

You need to use PowerShell to provision the deployment by using AVD.json.

Which PowerShell cmdlet should you use?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D. Register the Microsoft.VirtualMachineImages resource provider.

To use Azure VM Image Builder to update your custom virtual machine image (Image1), the first step is to register the Microsoft.VirtualMachineImages resource provider. This resource provider is necessary for using the Azure VM Image Builder service.

questions.question_text:

You need to use Azure VM Image Builder to update Image1.

What should you do first?
